verses.text: But Jesus went to the Mount of Olives.
verses.comment: Jesus leaves the city for the Mount of Olives, a frequent place of prayer and solitude (cf. Luke 22:39). This mirrors Old Testament patterns of seeking God on mountains.

verses.text: Early in the morning he came again to the temple. All the people came to him, and he sat down and began to teach them.
verses.comment: Jesus teaches in the temple, showing his authority and role as a Rabbi. Sitting was the typical posture of teachers in Jewish tradition.

verses.text: The scribes and the Pharisees brought in a woman caught in adultery, and setting her in the midst,
verses.comment: The scribes and Pharisees appeal to the Law of Moses, which required punishment for adultery (Lev. 20:10).

verses.text: they said to him, 'Teacher, this woman has been caught in the very act of adultery.'
verses.comment: Their address of Jesus as 'Teacher' is respectful but also intended as a test. The situation is meant to trap him.

verses.text: Now in the Law, Moses commanded us to stone such women. What then do you say about her?
verses.comment: They reference the Mosaic Law which prescribes stoning for adultery (Deut. 22:22-24). They are pressing Jesus to choose between mercy and strict justice.

verses.text: They said this to test him, that they might have a charge to bring against him. But Jesus bent down and began to write with his finger on the ground.
verses.comment: The act of writing recalls Jeremiah 17:13 and may signify judgment or divine authority. Jesus does not answer immediately, avoiding their trap.

verses.text: When they kept on questioning him, he straightened up and said to them, 'Let the one among you who is without sin be the first to cast a stone at her.'
verses.comment: Jesus upholds the Law but appeals to the conscience of the accusers, requiring moral integrity in judgment (cf. Deut. 17:7).

verses.text: And again he stooped down and wrote on the ground.
verses.comment: No detail is given on what Jesus writes, maintaining the focus on the accusers' response. Some see symbolism in Jesus writing the Law as God did on stone tablets.

verses.text: When they heard it, they went out one by one, beginning with the oldest, until only Jesus was left, with the woman standing before him.
verses.comment: Their consciences are convicted, and they depart. Only Jesus, the sinless One, remains as final judge.

verses.text: Jesus stood up and said to her, 'Woman, where are they? Has no one condemned you?'
verses.comment: Jesus uses a respectful address ('woman'), the same word he uses for his own mother (John 2:4; 19:26), and invites her to recognize her deliverance (see Rom. 8:34).

verses.text: She said, 'No one, Lord.' And Jesus said, 'Neither do I condemn you; go, and from now on sin no more.'
verses.comment: Here, Jesus models both mercy and a call to transformation—true forgiveness leads to change. He does not minimize the sin, but offers the possibility of restoration.

verses.text: Then Jesus spoke to them again, saying, 'I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will not walk in darkness, but will have the light of life.'
verses.comment: 'I am the light of the world' is a clear claim of divinity and fulfillment of prophecy (cf. Isa. 42:6). Jesus alone brings saving, guiding light.

verses.text: So the Pharisees said to him, 'You bear witness about yourself; your testimony is not true.'
verses.comment: The Pharisees challenge Jesus, citing the requirement for multiple witnesses in the Law (Deut. 17:6; John 5:31).

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Even if I bear witness about myself, my testimony is true, because I know where I came from and where I am going. But you do not know where I come from or where I am going.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ divine origin makes his testimony valid; he speaks with authority unique to the One sent from God.

verses.text: You judge according to the flesh; I judge no one.
verses.comment: Worldly judgment is contrasted with the divine perspective. Jesus’ mission focuses not on condemnation but on salvation.

verses.text: Yet if I do judge, my judgment is true, for I am not alone, but I and the Father who sent me.
verses.comment: Jesus’ unity with the Father means his judgment is authoritative and just (cf. John 5:30).

verses.text: In your law it is written that the testimony of two people is true.
verses.comment: Jesus uses the Law’s rule of testimony to further his case, demonstrating knowledge and fulfillment of the Mosaic covenant.

verses.text: I am the one who bears witness about myself, and the Father who sent me bears witness about me.
verses.comment: The Father publicly testifies to the Son at Jesus’ baptism and through his works (John 5:37; Matt. 3:17).

verses.text: They said to him, 'Where is your Father?' Jesus answered, 'You know neither me nor my Father. If you knew me, you would know my Father also.'
verses.comment: Intimate union with God is only found in relationship to Jesus. Knowing the Son reveals the Father (John 14:7-9).

verses.text: He spoke these words in the treasury, while teaching in the temple; and no one arrested him, because his hour had not yet come.
verses.comment: Divine timing governs Jesus' ministry—no human intervention can alter the Father’s plan. ‘Hour’ refers to the time of Jesus’ sacrifice.

verses.text: Again he said to them, 'I am going away, and you will seek me, and you will die in your sin. Where I am going, you cannot come.'
verses.comment: Separation from Christ means remaining in sin. Only those united to Him through faith (and, by extension, sacramental union) can follow him into eternal life.

verses.text: So the Jews said, 'Will he kill himself, since he says,
verses.comment: Once again, they misunderstand Jesus' words, revealing spiritual blindness. The inability to follow Jesus points to the necessity of grace and spiritual rebirth.

verses.text: He said to them, 'You are from below; I am from above. You are of this world; I am not of this world.'
verses.comment: Jesus clearly distinguishes his divine origin. Believers are called to be not of this world, following the path Christ sets (John 17:14).

verses.text: That is why I told you that you will die in your sins. For unless you believe that I am he, you will die in your sins.'
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus' divine identity ('I am') is necessary for salvation. The phrase recalls God's self-revelation to Moses: 'I AM.'

verses.text: So they said to him, 'Who are you?' Jesus answered them, 'Exactly what I have been telling you from the beginning.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms His identity is consistent throughout His ministry. His divinity and mission have been revealed since the start.

verses.text: 'I have many things to say and judge concerning you, but he who sent me is true, and I declare to the world what I have heard from him.'
verses.comment: Jesus reveals only what the Father gives him, fulfilling the prophetic mission and acting as the Father's faithful ambassador.

verses.text: They did not understand that he was speaking to them about the Father.
verses.comment: A recurring theme in John's Gospel is spiritual blindness among Jesus' listeners regarding his unity with the Father.

verses.text: So Jesus said to them, 'When you have lifted up the Son of Man, then you will know that I am he, and that I do nothing on my own authority, but speak just as the Father has taught me.'
verses.comment: 'Lifted up' refers both to the cross and Christ's exaltation. The phrase 'I am' again connects to God's self-identification.

verses.text: 'And he who sent me is with me; he has not left me alone, for I always do the things that are pleasing to him.'
verses.comment: Jesus' absolute obedience and perfect union with the Father fulfill the prophecy of the Suffering Servant.

verses.text: As he spoke these things, many believed in him.
verses.comment: Despite opposition, faith arises in those open to Christ's words. This foreshadows the growing Church.

verses.text: So Jesus said to the Jews who had believed him, 'If you continue in my word, you are truly my disciples,'
verses.comment: Discipleship demands perseverance—faith and obedience must continue, foreshadowing the Church's doctrine of ongoing faithfulness.

verses.text: 'and you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.'
verses.comment: Jesus Himself is the Truth (John 14:6), and full freedom comes through Him.

verses.text: They answered him, 'We are offspring of Abraham and have never been enslaved to anyone. How is it that you say,
verses.comment: The Jews' confidence in their ancestry underscores the importance of spiritual adoption over merely physical descent.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'Truly, truly I say to you, everyone who commits sin is a slave to sin.'
verses.comment: Slavery to sin is a condition Christ alone overcomes — a spiritual principle reaffirmed by Paul (Rom. 6:16).

verses.text: 'The slave does not remain in the house forever; the son remains forever.'
verses.comment: Jesus draws a distinction between permanent membership in God's family and temporary association. This points to the importance of sonship and remaining in faithful relationship.

verses.text: 'So if the Son sets you free, you will be free indeed.'
verses.comment: True spiritual freedom comes only through Christ. This verse has been deeply influential in both doctrine and Christian spirituality.

verses.text: 'I know that you are offspring of Abraham; yet you seek to kill me because my word finds no place in you.'
verses.comment: Being Abraham's descendants physically is not enough—an openness to Christ’s word is essential.

verses.text: 'I speak of what I have seen with my Father, and you do what you have heard from your father.'
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts divine revelation with the world’s influence, hinting that lineage is spiritual, not merely biological.

verses.text: They answered and said to him, 'Abraham is our father.' Jesus said to them, 'If you were Abraham's children, you would be doing the works Abraham did.'
verses.comment: Spiritual kinship is proven by obedience, reflecting Abraham’s faith and trust in God.

verses.text: 'But now you seek to kill me, a man who has told you the truth that I heard from God. Abraham did not do this.'
verses.comment: Contrast between Abraham’s hospitality (Gen. 18) and the hostile actions of the opponents of Jesus.

verses.text: 'You are doing the works your father did.' They said to him, 'We were not born of sexual immorality. We have one Father—even God.'
verses.comment: Jesus exposes the spiritual heritage of his opponents. The crowd claims God as Father, but Jesus insists true sonship is revealed by actions.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'If God were your Father, you would love me, for I came from God and I am here. I did not come of my own accord, but he sent me.'
verses.comment: Loving Jesus is inseparable from being a true child of God. This sets the standard for faithful Christian belief.

verses.text: 'Why do you not understand what I say? It is because you cannot bear to listen to my word.'
verses.comment: Spiritual deafness is foretold by Isaiah. Only those receptive to grace can understand Christ’s teaching.

verses.text: 'You are of your father the devil, and your will is to do your father’s desires. He was a murderer from the beginning, and does not stand in the truth, because there is no truth in him. When he lies, he speaks from his own nature, for he is a liar and the father of lies.'
verses.comment: Jesus directly unmasks the hidden evil at work, identifying Satan as the source of all lies and opposition to the truth.

verses.text: 'But because I tell the truth, you do not believe me.'
verses.comment: Rejection of Christ stems not from falsehood, but from willful resistance to divine truth.

verses.text: 'Which one of you convicts me of sin? If I tell the truth, why do you not believe me?'
verses.comment: Jesus' sinlessness is unique, further confirming his divine identity. Only the sinless Mediator can redeem mankind.

verses.text: 'Whoever is of God hears the words of God. The reason you do not hear them is that you are not of God.'
verses.comment: Obedient hearts are needed to accept divine teaching—an early reference to the necessity of remaining under true authority.

verses.text: The Jews answered him, 'Are we not right in saying that you are a Samaritan and have a demon?'
verses.comment: Accusing Jesus of being a Samaritan or demon-possessed is an attempt to discredit him; yet, Jesus endures such attacks as foretold regarding God's prophets.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'I do not have a demon, but I honor my Father, and you dishonor me.'
verses.comment: Honoring the Son equals honoring the Father, showing the importance of reverence for Christ.

verses.text: 'Yet I do not seek my own glory; there is One who seeks it, and he is the judge.'
verses.comment: Jesus' humility reveals his complete submission to the Father's will, an example for all followers.

verses.text: 'Truly, truly, I say to you, if anyone keeps my word, he will never see death.'
verses.comment: Eternal life is granted to those who faithfully keep Christ's word. This foreshadows both perseverance and participation in the Church’s sacramental life.

verses.text: The Jews said to him, 'Now we know that you have a demon! Abraham died, as did the prophets, yet you say,
verses.comment: Their misunderstanding again highlights their purely earthly perspective regarding death. Jesus speaks of spiritual life.

verses.text: 'Are you greater than our father Abraham, who died? And the prophets died! Who do you make yourself out to be?'
verses.comment: They question Jesus’ superiority over Abraham. The Gospel has repeatedly shown Christ as greater (cf. John 4:12).

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'If I glorify myself, my glory is nothing. It is my Father who glorifies me, of whom you say,
verses.comment: Jesus seeks only the Father’s will and glory, modeling perfect humility.

verses.text: 'But you have not known him. I know him. If I were to say that I do not know him, I would be a liar like you, but I do know him and I keep his word.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ knowledge of the Father is unique and full—he alone perfectly keeps the Father’s commands and reveals them.

verses.text: 'Your father Abraham rejoiced that he would see my day. He saw it and was glad.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims that Abraham anticipated the Messiah’s day — a spiritual insight fulfilled in Christ. Many Church Fathers saw Isaac’s near-sacrifice as a foreshadowing of Christ’s Passion.

verses.text: So the Jews said to him, 'You are not yet fifty years old, and have you seen Abraham?'
verses.comment: The question is literal, but Jesus’ claim is spiritual and timeless—warning against a merely temporal understanding of His person.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, before Abraham was, I AM.'
verses.comment: This is one of the clearest direct declarations by Jesus of his divinity, connecting to God’s covenant name revealed to Moses. The present tense ‘I AM’ refers to eternal existence.

verses.text: So they picked up stones to throw at him; but Jesus hid himself and went out of the temple.
verses.comment: The crowd sought to stone Jesus for blasphemy, realizing the implication of His words. Yet, His divine mission could not be thwarted until the appointed time.
